text: Hi! I am just starting the planning phase for an Italy trip. How is the weather in mid to late October? The ultimate for me would be Rome, the Amalfi coast, and some other sites. I’m not a beachgoer, so going to the beach is not a dealbreaker. Thank you!

comments.comment_text: Perfect time to travel

Last year when I was in Italy October was great warm & im going again this year so my clothes are all cotton, linen, silk with an umbrella & cardigan. It has changed as I have been going for 16 years as I stayed 3 months and always left mid October & it was freezing 🌻
Perfect weather!
Went to Rome and Amalfi last year at that time. 70 and sunny for 12 days
The first half of October is better than the second half. The rainy season typically kicks in towards the end of the month.

I have been there many, many times in October. And the weather has been good for me. With global warming who knows that may change a little. I think you will be safe. Glad you're going to amalfi. It's our favorite place

text:
Hello
I need help with my Italy itinerary. I’m traveling to Italy after 4 days in London. There 6 adults and 2 kids.
I will have 7 days. I know I want to go to Florence. Can someone help me where should I go next. Milan Rome etc ??
I will be flying home from London.
What is better option fly or train ?
Any Airbnb/ hotel recommendations ?
This last minute plan ( family members bucket list)
Thank you!

comments.comment_text: We loved Cinque Terre, Florence and of course Venice. The Vatican and Colosseum were fantastic but Rome is so crowded. Google some itineraries for ideas.
How old are your kids?

Where are you flying into? ￼
Which London airport are you flying home from? These factors weigh in on my response.

Go to Milano. You can fly directly from London and there is a great train transportation system.

You can use Milano as a base and have 1 day trips to Verona, Como area, Bergamo(Capital
of culture for 2023) What to see in Milano - Cathedral, going up the Cathedral, Castello Sforzesco, Pinacoteca di Brera (which takes probably at least half a day), Brera neighborhood, visit Teatro La Scala, have aperitivo in the Navigli area. Kids would love visiting the Leonardo Da Vinci Museum and maybe renting bikes in the Sempione park.

Also from Milano, you can easily reach Florence and maybe stay there 2 nights.
I agree with Rome, Florence and Venice for first time to Italy travellers.
3 days Florence, 4 days Rome.
7 days=2 major cities. Rome or Venice would be recommended. Take train to other city.
4 days Rome, 3 days Florence. Bear in mind you also have to allow for travel days, so that 7 days might actually be 6, so adjust accordingly.
Use a travel agent!

I would stay in Florence and do day trips to Pisa and Tuscany. There is sooo much to do in Florence, 3 days wasn’t enough for me, and I didn’t have a 6 year old.
I just think it would be less stressful not having to change locations.

Two suggestions: Venice, it's a different experience from other cities and it's close to Firenze using fast trains. But Rome is also different and has lots of history, close to Firenze as well. Tough choice but those are my recommendations
.

I just came back from a trip there, I would recommend if you have not been in Paris, fly to paris it is beautiful. Two nights should be enough and flight from London to Paris should be cheap. I would then go to Rome and after maybe Venice and Florence. Those were my 4 favorite cities, I went all over in Italy, France and only Barcelona in Spain but Venice, Paris, Florence and Rome were my absolute favorite, besides Sorrento that is!

Honestly if you only have 7 days with so many people including kids you are better off staying in Florence and take day trips. In addition to wealth of art and culture and food in Florence, your group can take a train or tour to Siena, Piza, Lucca Arezzo and many other places in the area. No need to waste time on transit, hotel change etc. which eats up lot of time
Fly and up to you re where? Lakes districts lovely and Tuscany / Umbria

Just finishing a trip w teens and 75 yo parents. I’d say consider your kids and set yourself up for success! Work in a golf cart tour, e-bikes, pizza/gelato/
pasta making or a swim. I did Rome, Venice, Florence and 5 terre. Kinda wish I’d done garda lake instead for a break but also then would not have seen Venice!

Fly to Florence and stay there: 1 day trip to Venice, 1 day trip to Pisa and Lucca (in Pisa be sure to show the kids the Keith Haring painting, the church in Piazza dei Cavalieri with flags of the real arab pirates from the Crusades and to climb the tower, in Lucca in the morning hire some bicycles and ride long the walls), 1 day trip to Siena and the Chianti area, then 1 day trip either in val d’Orcia or 5 terre.
You will have seen plenty of stuff, done speed train to Venice, the kids will have enjoyed nice places (Monterosso in 5 terre is the town from the movie Luca, Leaning Tower, gondola rides, bike rides, climbing to the roof of the Cathedral in Florence, gelato, high speed train…) all without changing hotel every 2 days.
If you only have 7 days then I would say Florence & Rome
Be aware carry on requirements in Europe are different than the USA (smaller size in Europe) - not sure where ur home is.
Probably Rome over Milan, to cater for everyone's interests and ages. Have been with high school students in Milan, and really ,apart from the duomo, it is just a large city.
Hire a travel advisor

In my opinion if you have only 7 days stay in Tuscany -skip Rome and Milan… enjoy your time in one area without racing around… go to Siena, San Gimignano, tour the Chianti region, maybe Lucca. If anything, drive up to Bologna and visit for a couple days.
F
Sopra la Roccia
Se arrivi da londra arrivi dal nord europa. Volo per MILANO poi scendi la penisola puoi fare Bologna Firenze, Lucca, Roma e via a svendere o risalire

In seven days I would suggest you to don't rush from an highlights to another so visit only two places, maybe Rome and Florence.
But it depends from period of the year and your interests (art, culture, tradition, beaches, landscapes, Archeologic sites, landscapes and sceneries and so on), e.g. in summer you could visit 5T and North big lakes or Amalfi Coast, Capri, Ischia, Procida and Naples.

Since there are 6 adults plus 2 children I would suggest spliting your days between Florence and Rome..fly into Rome and make this your base..look into renting an AirBB, stay in Rome for 3 days I would suggest renting a car and day trips to Florence and other places in between..fly out of Rome back to London. Leave Milan for another time..
Rome. Unless you want to see The Last Supper and the Basilica in Milan. Maybe Sforza Castle too

Murano, Venice, Florence, Tuscany
are all beautiful places. Save Rome for another time.

I would go to Florence and stay there. You could take a train to Venice for the day. We did. It’s about 2.5-3 hours but takes you right into the heart of Venice from the heart of Florence. Then 1 day trip to Cinque Terre. Take the water ferry to the 5 towns, go to the Beach in Monterosso and then take the train back through the 5 towns. 3 days in Florence and then train to Rome for last two days and fly out of Rome
PS: Paris needs a trip by itself. City and then beaches of Normandy Lots of history makes the war much more real to youngsters

text: One day in Verona. Top tips?

comments.comment_text: Make sure you see the River

I am leaving today from Verona. In my opinion, in one day:
1 - Go to Castel Vecchio and bridge Scalieri, arco di Gavi;
- after, come back and go to the arena, take fotos in Piazza Bra (in my opinion you haven't enough time to go inside the arena but you can see if you want...)you have a direct street in front of the castel that goes to Piazza Bra.
2 - Then go to Piazza Erbe, Julieta House and Piazza della Signoria.they are all near by!
3 - Go to Ponte Pietra/ bridge and the castel of S. Peter to see the city.
4- In the return, if you have time and if you want, go to the Bosari gate and near Castel Vecchio you have the S. Zeno Church. I really enjoy it, and i don't go to see them usually ( the church). I dont know when it is closed... i went at 15 p.m. but i had two days...
5 - To eat, near the arena, with a "coberto" fee lower that in Piazza Bra ( they charged me coberto and service fee in piazza bra!!), you have a pizzaria named Crocca, very nice, big individual pizzas and other plates, with "the fork" discount, if you make reservations in the app.
ENJOY!!
ITs a small but lovely city!!
Get a Verona card
See a show in the Roman amphitheater
Attend the Opera - incredible experience at the arena in Verona. I’ve been each time visiting Verona and would definitely go again 🇮🇹❤️🥂
Watch out for pickpocketers all the time!

text:
Hi,
I'm visiting Rome and I'm not sure if it's because all the walking that I have been doing around Italy, but my legs started turning red and swallow. Never happened to me before. Have any of you had to visit ever the ER in Rome? What are your suggestions?
Thank you

comments.comment_text: Air travel. Get some compression socks.

Disney Rash. I let mine go way too far! I was on a whirlwind trip with students last summer in Europe. Soak a washcloth in ice /cold water and prop up legs. Finally got a pair of compression tights / socks in Rome. I did go to the ER in Spain, but wasting a day waiting and the fact that there’s not much that can be done was not worth losing a day
Definitely Disney rash/golfers rash. I got it’s Dubai walking around in extreme heat. Looks worse than it is and eventually goes away.

Last year, while in Rome, my knee blew up and I became unable to bear weight on it. The concierge at my hotel called a doctor to come see me. He was very helpful. I did try to get to an ER but the taxi driver we found didn’t understand English.
There’s an English speaking clinic I went to when I broke my arm in Italy and had the best experience.
Happens to me all the time on the golf course. Did you have sunscreen applied? Along with lotion and heat with sweat? Does it burn and itch?
Try a pharmacy, they may be able to help you
Hot

Go to
ER
Go to Dr. El medico. This looks nasty
It looks like cellulitis. Go to a doctor.

I went to a clinic in Italy. With something this obvious you won’t need to speak Italian. They do have “tourist” clinics that essentially have an English speaking staff person. Our hotel helped us find one. Ironically, the day I went the English speaker wasn’t working. Made my way with google translate easy enough.
Seyed Emamamzadeh

Please go to the ER.
Your emergency medical insurance covers ER cost and whatever meds you need. And make sure you read your emergency medical insurance policy to find out if you need to let them know before treatment.
Sorry but i don't think anyone here is qualified to make a medical assessment. And if there is one, it would be difficult to determine what it is by just looking at the picture.
Please do yourself a favor and seek medical assistance asap.

Go see a doctor. Then bring all the receipts and submit it to your health insurance company for reimbursement. Or if you've purchased travel insurance, contact them to see if they'll cover anything. But yes! Please see a doctor.

I had this when I was there too. All over my arms as well. It came on with some nausea. We think it was heat rash . I got over heated. ￼First time in my life. It went away and peeled. I put some Cortizone cream on it.
I agree with DISNEY Rash. I am a Disney World pass holder and get this every time for the past 7 years. Didn’t even know that was a thing until it happened to me.

Same thing happens with me. I think it’s related to heat, humidity, sweat, sunscreen and insect repellent. And mine affects me in the same place, lower leg. I also had a nasty bug bite on top of all this which became infected and I went to the emergency tourist clinic in Venice. Antibiotics cleared it up but I have remnant discoloration that’s still healing from 6 weeks ago.
I’m heavy this happens to me when it’s hot, sweaty and I’m doing a lot more walking then my body is used to.
Looks like a heat rash! Exactly what my sister’s legs looked like after spending time on the beach in Mexico. Some people are ultra sensitive to heat and sun. And she only got it on her legs. ￼

Just so you know, I will already have my Saucony runners. I'm thinking more along the lines of appropriate shoes with a nice dress. The sandals I will be taking would be perfect but not if it's too cold to wear them. Thank you everyone.

comments.comment_text: Generally no.
I would check il Meteo for the weather before you go.

They don't allow flip flops, but we both hiked Cinque Terre in covered sandals on a very warm day in late September. And have spent many days all over Italy including Tuscany, lakes, and Dolomites in September and October with sandals. There may be days in October when you might want a sweater, mostly in evenings, but sweaters and sandals do go together.
Thin leather soles aren’t the best choice for the ancient cobblestone streets. No padding and no traction. A sport-type sandal will provide the most stability and comfort.
It is still warm mid to late September.

We always travel to Tuscany, think Orvieto, Arezzo, Siena, Montepulciano and around that area. I have always worn sandals and we walk a lot. If I would need other shoes well I am in Italy. They sell shoes.
Sorry we go in October and May.
Get a pair of comfy sneakers
Wear sketchers there comfy n some really nice styles too
yes
I've had loads of beautiful, sunny times in Tuscany in September. Definitely bring sandals but also comfortable sneakers in case of an odd showery day. I've never been cold

We were in Tuscany in late September,early
October and sandals were just fine. It was lovely during the day and cooled down to sweater weather in the evening

text:
Hello! When travelling with a group, how do people pay at restaurants? Is it frowned upon to ask for separate bills? Should we be paying by Euros, or can we all pay separately with Credit Card? TIA!

*Edit* Thank you everyone! I received the answers I was looking for, so I turned off the comments. 🥰

comments.comment_text: I would not expect them to split the bill. Use the app Splitwise to keep track of who owes what and then just pay each other later.

They don’t really need to split the bill. When they come with the machine, just tell them how much to charge for each card. I wouldn’t do this with more than a few cards though. Three friends and we split the bill sometimes 1 all cash and the rest on a card. Other times, 2 cards. Yes, paying all cash per person for a large group is always the way to go. I would not want to be dealing with apps of who owes what.
I’d definitely figure that out on your end! Keep track and send money through Venmo or cash.
They do not like to split the bill
They split the bill if you want just work it out yourselves and tell them how much you each want to pay ! We didn’t have a problem , somethings we even paid some cash some card
Have a Kitty

Separate bills could be a problem. Why don´t you each pay for what you eat and drink and put in a little for a tip (if you so wish), this way it is fair to everyone? This way if someone orders something much more expensive be it drink or food, they just pay their fair share instead of splitting the bill equally, otherwise someone else has to pay more for the extra expensive consumed and this could cause some stress when the next meal and bill comes around.
Separate checks is not common there.. bring cash

It really depends, there are places where you can tell what you ordered and pay just that, places where they divide the total for the number of people and everyone will pay the same, and there are places that don’t split the bill. It’s a good idea to ask when you arrive so you know what to expect when it’s time to pay. Also, it’s not legal for restaurant (or shops or taxi) to not accept credit cards

We are in Italy rn. In Lucca it was not an option and in Rome it is not an option. I am traveling with my bf and family we are 7 people and we have to keep track of who eats what to then pay back the one person paying.
If you trust who you’re with, use SplitWise app. It’s great for this use case.
Separate checks is time-consuming for the server who may be very busy.

If you’re family or close friends (as opposed to people you just met on your tour group) I highly suggest everyone paying a set amount into a kitty from which restaurant bills are paid. This only works if you trust the people you’re sharing with to not consistently over-order or to at least supplement the kitty if they’re frequently the only one who orders more to eat/drink than the others. When the kitty needs to be fed, everyone kicks in the same amount. We’ve done this on several trips with extended family members and it either for us.
They did not split any bills for us! We traded off and if I would have known I would have used splitwise
Take turns to pay
Four of us just got back from two weeks in Italy. Used Splitwise for everything including taxi fares, so easy. Paid up upon returning to the US.

Just travelled with 3 other families. Get the bill. Each family uses their phone calculator to add up what their family ordered. All restaurants allowed 4 different credit card transactions but won’t separate the bill for you. The final day of our trip we had it down to a science.
Another vote for Splitwise app. It makes it so easy to keep track and settle up at the end of the trip.
Thank you for asking this specific question. I was wondering the same thing.

Yes, that is true for the Corniglia train station. Corniglia is the only village in Cinque Terre that is not located on the coast, but rather on a hilltop. The train station is located at the bottom of the hill, and the only way to get to the village is by climbing the 380 steps of the Lardarina staircase.

If you are coming by train from Florence, you will first arrive at the Monterosso al Mare train station. From there, you can take a local train to the Corniglia train station. The train ride is only about 5 minutes, but it is important to note that there are only a few trains per day that stop at Corniglia.

If you are not up for the climb, there is a shuttle bus that runs from the train station to the village center. The shuttle bus costs €1.50 per person, and it runs every 10-15 minutes.

Here are some other things to keep in mind if you are planning on visiting Corniglia:

* The village is very small, so it is easy to get around on foot.
* There are no cars allowed in the village, so you will need to walk or take the shuttle bus to get around.
* There are a few restaurants and shops in the village, but it is not a large tourist destination, so there are not as many options as in the other villages of Cinque Terre.
* The views from the village are amazing, so be sure to take your time and enjoy them!

From the five towns, that’s Corniglia. It was great to visit it but not to stay since you’d have to do those steps every day and more than once. However, they have a mini bus that will take you up the town but I never used it so I’m not sure how it works.

text: We only have one day in Rome. What are the top places we should see?

comments.comment_text: Vatican, castle st. Angelo, then walk around and see Spanish steps, Trevi fountain and the pantheon. Prato ares has great restaurants as well as a huge market.
The Vatican, Spanish steps, trevi fountain. That should take a day

1.The Vatican ( St Peter's Basilica and Museum)

2 . Trevi Fountain and the other sites surrounding the area.

3. The Colloseum

Do the Vatican in the morning if you want to see the basilica and the museum because the lines are crazy during the day! After that Trevi Fountain and the other sites surrounding it such as the Pantheon. By the afternoon you should be able to visit the Colloseum with the crowds dying down 😌

But depending on your schedule hope you have enough time to do what you want to do! Enjoy your time in Roma 💪

Spanish Steps, Pantheon, and Trevi are all walking, short stops. Start at Spanish Steps and work way to Pantheon. From Pantheon eat lunch at/in the Piazzo Navona. Then taxi to Colossuem for a tour or just see it from road and taxi on over to piazzale giuseppe garibaldi (park) for sunset w views of city. Then, walk down hill to Trastevere for dinner/drinks. It’ll be an action packed day and you’ll be tired but you will have DONE IT! lol
Take a on and off bus tour. You can see all the sights and get off where you want to take pictures then take the next bus. Not a long wait in between. It was great!

cancellable) reserved for next year. We also have back-up reservations with hotels that can easily be cancelled online within 24 hours (hopefully won't be needed). Most hosts will also leave a list of restaurant recommendations, taxi instructions, etc. (Some have already provided this information to us many months out). A few will arrange car service from the airport or train station at reasonable rates. You don't need a travel agent, you just need to be thorough and organized. If you are an Apple user, Numbers has a template called Travel Planner that's a great start in organizing your plans.

We're working with JayWay Travel for a customized trip for 2. Very happy with them. They gave us several hotels to pick from for each city. They are making travel arrangements like train, airport transfers to hotel, asked what type of tours we'd lijevto do and gave us a list to pick from. In the US I usually make all the plans myself but was not comfortable doing that in Italy especially since we don't speak Italian. I checked reviews for the hotel choices before picking one.
Kris Levy :Donovan Travel

We used railbookers they booked our hotels and train tickets. They booked some of our tours also. I would definitely recommend viator for some tours. We took the gold carry tour in Rome and it was the best tour we took the whole trip. It took us everywhere even places we would never see it was great it was 4 of us and we loved it
I would get a travel agent to book your hotels and trains. All tours you can book yourself but it is so nice to have the other stuff arranged for you with no extra cost.
Lavishly Travel they know Italy very well.

We used Cultural Italy to help us with the part of our trip in Rome. They were amazing. They booked our train tickets from Florence to Italy, arranged for us to picked up at the train station and taken to our hotel, booked a golf cart tour on the afternoon of our arrival, booked private tours of the Roman Forum/
Colosseum, and arranged our transportation from our hotel in Rome to our hotel at the airport. Them taking care of everything really made the trip stress free and enjoyable!

"The sights" aren't easy to visit via car because Rome is filled with them. You will also have to figure out how to avoid ZTLs. I've driven in Rome, but I'm normally going to one destination. If you hire a driver, they will have access to places you can't drive.

Maybe hire a driver who picks you up at the airport and drives you around Rome for a few hours. Then, when you're ready to leave Rome after your stay there, pick up your car from Termini on your way out of the city.

text: We will be in Bologna for 4 nights. Any thoughts about day trips from there? Is Parma, Italy worth visiting, or should we go to Florence to visit places we missed?

comments.comment_text: I loved Verona. It was smaller. Amazing restaurants. Amazing tours. One of my favorite towns in Italy.

Bologna is surrounded by beautiful hills full of osterias, and the local cuisine is one of the best in Italy. Parma historical centre is nice, but if you haven't seen Florence I'd do that first. From Bologna you can reach most places easily by train, including Venice and Pisa, you might want to check that out.

Parma is absolutely worth visiting. Fabulous food (even better than Bologna despite what everyone thinks) a few beautiful museums, lots of terrific shopping and it’s completely walkable. Can’t say enough good thinks.
